fields.text: Try making a smoothie today! It will help you get in your recommended fruits/veggies per day and it’s delicious! Orange juice with banana and frozen blueberries or strawberries make a great combination.  Put in a blender for about 1 minute and you've got a great grab and go breakfast snack!

Did you know that garlic, onions, leeks, asparagus and chives all contain chemicals that stimulate the immune system?  Try tossing some fresh garlic into your next pasta dish.  Load up on them now and keep those cold germs at bay!
When making soups, try using tomato juice for a tasty healthy alternative to other types of broth!  Tastes great and adds a freg serving to your soup!

Try making a homemade salsa for get-togethers with friends; they are full of nutrients and vegetables and you can control the ingredients; mix together tomato, garlic, onion, spices, and any of your favorite vegetables and enjoy with whole -wheat tortilla chips.
Instead of frying your vegetables, bake them.  Toss  cut vegetables such as sweet potatoes,  zucchini, eggplant  or tomatoes with olive oil, salt,pepper and garlic and bake in the oven until soft.

Red fruits and vegetables, such as red cabbage, tomatoes, and watermelon, can help reduce the negative impact of sun damage on your skin.  Try shredding some red cabbage (or buy it shredded) and sautéing it with extra virgin olive oil, apple cider vinegar, sugar and onions.  Add mustard seed to make it extra tasty!
Orange fruits and vegetables, such as apricots, carrots, cantaloupe, and squash, can help fight cancer and help with your vision.  Baby carrots are easy to pack as a snack for the day.
Did you know that kiwis have twice the Vitamin C as an orange?  And, they’re delicious as a take-along snack. Just slice and eat.
Green and yellow fruits and vegetables, such as peas, corn, avocado, and honeydew melon, can help with vision health.  Cut avocados in half, take out the pit, and scoop out with a spoon to eat.

White and green vegetables, such as onions, pears, chives, and celery, have many anti-viral and anti-bacterial benefits on the body.  Chop up some chives and add them to your next meal.  Your taste buds will thank you.

Explore the produce aisle and choose something new. Variety is the key to a healthy diet. Get out of a rut and try some new fruits and vegetables. You can find recipe ideas online and learn ways to prepare these new freggies!
When buying fresh fruit, buy in season!  It’ll likely be cheaper.  Things that are available right now include collard greens, grapefruit, and pears.
Some fruits and vegetables are least expensive canned.  They include asparagus, sweet corn, and green beans! Look for store specials and coupons to get a great price on these freggies!

Look for heavy, firm cherries with a tight skin.  Be sure to pay attention to pits in each cherry.  Use a cherry pitter to pit the cherries over a bowl so you can make hear the pit click into the bowl and be sure that each cherry is successfully pitted.
Include variety with your meals; try to eat a new fruit/vegetable each day to avoid eating the same things day after day!
One way to help include fruits and veggies in your daily diet is by packing snacks on the go! Try packing mini carrots or grapes in sandwich bags so they are always with you.
In this cold weather, try warming up with a vegetable soup that can incorporate many servings of vegetables, such as tomato, minestrone, or traditional veggie soup.
Beans are a great source of fiber; try pinto beans, lima beans, or black beans in your daily diet.   They go great in salads and stir fries.

Vitamin C is an essential nutrient that can have many benefits on your health, such as cold and flu prevention.  Be sure to eat plenty of oranges, strawberries, peppers, Brussels sprouts, pineapple and other freggies full of Vitamin C this month.

The CDC’s fruit of the month for January is dried fruit.  Dried fruit makes a great grab and go snack. Put some in a sandwich bag to carry with you in your backpack.  Apricots, raisins, cherries and cranberries are great on their own or mixed with nuts for a vitamin and protein boost!

Avocado is a fruit! To prepare, wash, then cut in half lengthwise, going around the pit. Twist the two halves gently to separate. You can hit the pit with a knife to remove it, or you can cut the avocado in half lengthwise again and gently pry out the pit. Pull off the skin with your fingers and slice or scoop out. Sprinkle with lemon juice if you aren't serving it immediately to stop enzymatic browning.

The CDC’s vegetable of the month for January is tubers.  They include yucca root, taro root, and water chestnuts.  You can cook yucca much like you would a potato.  Just peel, and boil.  Then, try cutting it in strips, seasoning it, and baking it to make yucca fries!   Try a tuber today, be daring, and expand your taste buds!

Broccoli has so much fiber and so many nutrients, including those valuable phytochemicals. Choose firm, plump heads with no yellow florets and firm leaves. Separate the florets from the stalk, wash well and cook by steaming or boiling. If you don't undercook or overcook it, there won't be an unpleasant sulfur smell. The stalks can be peeled and cut into thin pieces. Begin cooking the stalks a few minutes before the florets so they are done at the same time.

Did you know that the blender is not just for smoothies and milkshakes?  You can use a blender to make creamy and delicious vegetables soups.  Try this one to get you started: put equal parts broccoli florets and milk or vegetable stock into a pot and allow it to cook until the broccoli is tender.  Add low-fat cheddar cheese and puree it in a blender.  Experiment with different seasonings (try nutmeg!) and various vegetables.
Apples are now thought to keep your brain sharp as you age, enhance memory, and potentially lessen the odds of getting Alzheimer's disease.  Slice one and munch on it during the day!

Red, blue, and purple fruits and vegetables, such as red apples, beets, strawberries, and blueberries, can help the body with blood clots and help with heart health and protect the body from heart disease.  To cook beets, wash, steam, or roast them in the oven until you can prick them with a fork, then peel the skins and eat.

Keep raw vegetables (carrots, peppers, radishes, grape tomatoes) washed, cut and ready to eat in visible containers in the refrigerator.  Pump up the flavor by dipping them in low-fat salad dressing, hummus, or peanut butter.

Eating at least 5 servings of fruits/vegetables each day can help reduce the risk of type 2 diabetes. When ordering a sandwich, ask for extra vegetables, such as lettuce, tomato, onion, green pepper, spinach, or cucumbers.
While fresh fruits and vegetables are great, don’t forget about dried, canned, and frozen freggies too!  They are often less expensive and they don’t spoil as quickly!
Keep fruit out where you can see it. That way you'll be more likely to eat it. Keep it out on the counter or in the front of the fridge.

The CDC’s fruit of the month for February is the star fruit. Star fruits are an excellent source of vitamin C, are low fat, and naturally sodium and cholesterol free. They don’t have to be peeled or seeded so you can just grab a star fruit and enjoy!

Brussels sprouts are tasty and good for you!  And they’re available fresh right now!  Just wash, cut off the stems and pull off the bruised leaves, and make a small x at the base.  Put a small amount of water in the bottom of a pan and put them on top.  Steam until they are bright green and crisp-tender when pierced with a  fork.

Trying to manage your weight?  Eating fruits and vegetables is a great way to stay trim because they are packed with vitamins and minerals, low in calories but high into a volume.  That means you can feel fuller without consuming as many calories, and you’ll have more energy too!  Make it a rule to always carry some with you.
Vegetables that are better for you tend to be richer in color.  So pass on that iceberg lettuce and try something darker and healthier like Romaine or spinach!

Some fruits and vegetables are actually least expensive in their fresh form.  They include apples, bananas, potatoes, and cauliflower! You can find them at the farmers’ markets or in your local grocery store.

Some fruits and vegetables are least expensive as juice.  They include oranges, pineapples, prunes, and tomatoes! Remember to look for 100% juice.  Juice is fine for some of your fruit and vegetable selection, but don’t rely on it solely because it’s higher in sugars and doesn’t have as much fiber as fresh fruits and vegetables.
Some fruits and vegetables are least expensive dried.  They include grapes (raisins) and apricots! Buy these in bulk and carry with you in your backpack!
Some fruits and vegetables are least expensive frozen.  They include raspberries, collard greens, and okra! It is easy to add frozen freggies to the dishes you’re preparing.

Pomegranates are in season during the winter months. They are hard shelled fruits with tiny edible seeds coated with a red fruity glaze. The seeds are the part you eat. To easily remove the seeds, cut the pomegranate in half and, using a spoon, whack the back of the fruit so the seeds come out in a shower. Then squeeze the empty halves to juice.  They can also be cut in half, put in a bowl of water and seeds can be pulled out with hands to avoid getting juice stains on your cutting board or counter.

Papayas are great for protein digestion and are very low in calories.  The large black papaya seeds are edible and taste peppery. To select, simply test the fruit to make sure it gives slightly with pressure from your palm. To eat, wash , cut in half lengthwise, scoop out the seeds, slice and then peel.
No time for freg?  Stock your pantry ahead of time with grab and go ideas like individual containers of no-sugar-added applesauce, prepackaged salads, fresh whole fruit, and canned soup.
Mix your favorite nuts with dried fruit such as cranberries, raisins, or apricots for a homemade trail mix to keep in your desk.
Here’s a quick and easy way to add freg to your meal: Add frozen vegetables like peas and broccoli to a casserole or pasta.
Ask for less cheese and more vegetable toppings on your pizza. Try onions, mushrooms, and bell peppers.
Today, try skipping your traditional dessert and enjoy something naturally sweet like a delicious pomegranate or some blackberries.

Blueberries are not as perishable as some other types of berries. They are usually sold in 1 pint containers. Sort them carefully and make sure to pull off any attached stems. Wash and dry on paper towels, then eat or use in recipes.
Adding fruit to your morning cereal is an easy way to get some freg and make breakfast even more delicious!
Eating a salad before dinner can help you to curb your appetite and get in some servings of freggies for the day!

Have some cantaloupe today! To check for ripeness, gently press against the vine end of the melon (larger indentation). The melon should give gently, and should smell sweet. Make sure to wash the cantaloupe before you cut it, to prevent food poisoning from spreading with the knife. Gently scoop out seeds with a spoon and cut the fruit into wedges or use a melon baller.
Have your greens or lettuce wilted and they just don’t look appetizing anymore?  Submerge them in cold water in a container in the refrigerator for the night and your greens will be revived!

Cranberries are delicious and very nutritious and not just for the holidays.  Try and get them with as little sugar as possible to avoid needless calories.  Just wash them and eat them for a healthy treat!
Why eat more fruits and veggies?  They add color, texture, and appeal to any plate! Chop them up and store them in your fridge for a quick addition to any meal!
Did you know that there are only 50 calories in ¾ cup of fresh raspberries? It’s hard to beat that! Wash them and keep them in the fridge for a quick snack anytime!

Why eat more fruits and veggies?  They provide fiber that helps fill you up and keeps your digestive system healthy. Freggies high in fiber include artichokes, soybeans, and black-eyed peas.  You can buy black-eyed peas in a can for a delicious side dish.

One great thing about fruits and veggies is how many different kids there are.  So if you don’t like something, that’s okay because there are plenty more just waiting to be tried. Here’s one you might not have tried:  dragon fruit.  Find your favorite freggies and enjoy!

Smoothies are an awesome way to get lots of different fruits and vegetables on the go!  Experiment with different combinations to get a wide range of vitamins and minerals!  Here are some ingredients to liven up your smoothies:  peanut butter, cherries, lemon, berries, yogurt, and even watermelon chunks.  It’s hard to go wrong with a smoothie!

You’d be surprised to know how much your eating habits influence the habits of your family and friends!  Eat right today and start a Freggie revolution! Offer fresh fruits and vegetables to your friends and family when they visit!
Add lots of vegetables to sandwiches. Lettuce, tomatoes, cucumbers, bell peppers, and avocado slices are flavorful choices.

Another reason fruits and vegetables are so great:  they contain a lot of fluid and electrolytes.  Move over, Gatorade! Eating food such as grapes, watermelon, tomatoes, and cucumbers can keep you better hydrated!

Fresh beets should be firm, round and smooth with no soft spots. They can be roasted or steamed. If you roast them unpeeled, they can be eaten like a baked potato. The red stain from beets is permanent, so cover your work surface with waxed paper as you work. Cut off the stem and root, wash and scrub thoroughly, then cook by boiling, roasting or steaming. After cooking the skins will slip off easily.
Go on an exotic food scavenger hunt and pick up something new today!  Try acai; it’s a “superfood” and is great in smoothies.

Prunes aren’t just for your grandma anymore!  They’re seeing a resurgence in popularity and are often called “dried plums” now.  They’re also rich in antioxidants and, of course, help with regularity.  Throw some in a bag and bring them to class for a quick snack!
Remember food safety when you’re working with fruits and vegetables!  Wash them thoroughly and follow all guidelines for that fruit or vegetable!  And then, dig in!
If you’re baking a cake, consider substituting apple sauce for the oil.  It’s a 1 to 1 substitution, adds a little fruit to your treat, and makes it much healthier!

Did you know that foods like peppers, potatoes, tomatoes, and eggplants can help protect lungs from cigarette smoke, reduce blood pressure, and promote weight control?  Try some today! Add them to your favorite dishes like chili, pasta, or casseroles.

Eating fruits and vegetables can help you improve your mood, and help you have increased concentration to keep you on track for those long days in class! Bring a fresh fruit or vegetable snack with you to go!

Squash is very healthy and easy to cook.  Winter squashes like butternut and acorn squash are a great choice this time of year.  Just wash them, cut them in half lengthwise, scrape out the seeds and stringy portion, and put them on a greased pan.  Bake for about 45 minutes in a 400 degree oven.  Delicious!

Grab some frozen berries! Frozen blueberries are typically the petite wild version, which have been found by scientists to contain more disease-thwarting antioxidants than their traditionally cultivated counterparts (the type you're most likely to find fresh right now). Also, fresh blueberries are pricey in winter and, if trucked in from afar, can go moldy fast.
Here’s a fun way to stock up on freggies: Add apple chunks, pineapple, grapes, raisins, celery, carrots, or green peppers to tuna or chicken salad.
Join a co-op, stop by a farmer’s market or better yet, start your own little garden!  It’s healthy for you and the economy to buy local produce!

Fresh baby spinach is soft and sweet with a wonderful nutty flavor. Cooked spinach has more available nutrients, however. Purchase spinach with crisp, deep green leaves with no bruises or soft spots. Wash thoroughly because it tends to be sandy. Steam the spinach with just the water that clings to its leaves for moisture, until it wilts and turns very deep green.

When it comes to passion fruit, a wrinkled skin is a sign of ripeness. Just wash them, cut them in half and scoop out the soft, sweet flesh with a spoon. They're excellent as a topping for ice cream or meringues.

Ripe peaches should be firm, yellow with a red or pink blush, smell sweet, and give slightly to palm pressure. Unless you are canning them, be sure to select freestone peaches, not cling – the pits in cling peaches are substantially more difficult to remove. Peaches can be blanched for 30 seconds in boiling water, then plunged into cold water. The skins will slip right off.
Use a microwave to quickly “zap” vegetables. White or sweet potatoes can be baked quickly this way—just remember to poke a few holes in them with a fork first.
Trying to make those fresh fruits and vegetables last a little longer?  Put them in a sealed bag or container and place them in the crisper in the bottom of the fridge! That’s what it’s there for!
Fruits and veggies are nature’s treat and easy to grab for a snack. Cut up snack-sized portions right after you buy them and store in the fridge so you can grab and go!

Filling up your plate with fiber-filled foods like fruits and vegetables makes your body work harder to digest them, thereby burning more calories. Add fruits and vegetables to your meals on a regular basis!
When you’re eating an apple, make sure you eat its peel, too.  It contains a lot of the antioxidants and half of its fiber.
Make half of your plate fruits and vegetables.  That’s the ticket to eating well! Buy fresh fruits and vegetables in season from farmers’ markets or at the grocery store.

Artichokes have a reputation for being tricky to eat, but they’re actually pretty easy and they’re great for you.  Accept the challenge! Artichokes can be steamed, microwaved, sautéed, or boiled, and can be added to other dishes or eaten whole. They’re a great source of fiber, folate, and magnesium!
Roast vegetables to bring out their flavor. Just drizzle them with a small amount of olive oil, and bake them in the oven until they are tender.  Experiment and have fun!
Mushrooms are a great food to eat in the winter.  They’re rich in flavor and low in calories! Wash and eat them raw, or sauté them in a little olive oil and add to your favorite dishes.
One delicious way to fill up on veggies is through a hearty, broth-based soup.  You’ll be surprised how many servings you can pack into one bowl.
One delicious way to fill up on veggies is through a hearty, broth-based soup.  You’ll be surprised how many servings you can pack into one bowl.

Zucchini is best if eaten when fairly young; the large football-like zucchini become tough and bitter. The skin is edible, so you can peel it or not as you like.  Also remember that zucchini can be used in some pretty tasty dishes like zucchini bread.
As the weather heats up, don’t forget that vegetables are also great to throw on the grill!  Throw them in a foil packet or put them on a skewer to make delicious kabobs.
